issues.title: Make the string representation of PolyStorageError more robust.
issues.body:
While working on [bug 687630](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=687630) I ran into an issue while processing crashes, and the error couldn't be output properly because `PolyStorageError` had been called with no arguments, which `PolyStorageError.__str__` could not properly handle.

This makes the method more robust to weird arguments so that it will print out the errors that occurred even if there are no arguments given. It also slightly changes the format of what was output, but none of the tests were relying on this anyway.

issues.title: Bug 1430181: Add an API endpoint (CrashStopData) to Socorro.
issues.body: The purpose of this endpoint is to have in one shot all the data needed by the webextension CrashStop which displays crash data in Bugzilla.

issues.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
issues.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

issues.title: Fix bug 1399305: Script deletion and creation of S3 bucket and ES indices in development environment.
issues.body:
This does 3 things:

1. Adds `docker/run_recreate_s3_buckets.sh`, which runs during `make dockersetup` and deletes and re-creates the `dev_bucket` S3 bucket used during development.
2. Adds a new Socorro app called `clear_es_indices`, run during `make dockersetup`, that clears all existing Elasticsearch indexes.
3. Adds a new Socorro app called `create_recent_es_indices`, run during `make dockerupdatedata`, that creates Elasticsearch indices for the next two weeks. This fixes the issues with the homepage and other views that pop up during local development when they're missing.

We don't have great support for testing changes to Elasticsearch, so I filed [bug 1429267](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1429267) as a followup to add better scaffolding such that we could add automated tests for scripts like these.

To test this:
1. Start with a Socorro installation that has processed some crashes.
2. Run `make dockersetup`. You should see logging output that looks something like this:

   ```
   Dropping and recreating S3 bucket...
   S3 container bucket is dev_bucket
   delete: s3://dev_bucket/v1/dump/01557534-e7c7-4936-970d-86f550180107
   (...snip...)
   ```

   You should also see a log line like this, indicating that the existing ES indices have been deleted:

   ```
   2018-01-10 01:22:23,085 DEBUG - clear_es_indices -  - MainThread - Deleted elasticsearch indices.
   ```
3. Run `make dockerupdatedata`. You should see logging output indicating that new ES indices have been created:

   ```
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,754 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201801
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,812 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201802
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,893 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201803
   ```
4. Run `docker-compose up webapp` and visit http://localhost:8000/home/product/Firefox. You should see a graph on the front page, although it may contain no data (you should not see an error message, which indicates the indices were not found).

issues.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
issues.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1424659 - nix consecutive spaces in signatures

Prior to this, it was possible (though rare) to have two spaces in a row
in signatures. That's tough because the webui shows that as a single
space and if you search for the single-space version, you won't get any
results.

This fixes that by establishing that signatures can't have more than 1
consecutive whitespace character. Further, this makes sure that all
non-space whitespace characters are converted to space and this
happens all before we truncate the signature.

I also changed SigTrunc to SigTruncate because "trunc" is an unnecessary
abbreviation.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1371428 - nix ' to '' in signature generation

For years, there's been a bit of code to "escape single quotes" in
Java and C signatures. As near as I can tell, it predates the current
era of Socorro requirements and was likely added for some reason that
is no longer relevant.

One consequence is that it makes searching for frames harder, so this
removes that behavior.

fixes bug 1416841 - nix .* at end of lines in siglist files

Since each line is a regexp that's joined with others with | and then
used with .match(), they're effectively all "startswith" type matches
so the .* at the end is superfluous.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1399305: Script deletion and creation of S3 bucket and ES indices in development environment.
pull_requests.body:
This does 3 things:

1. Adds `docker/run_recreate_s3_buckets.sh`, which runs during `make dockersetup` and deletes and re-creates the `dev_bucket` S3 bucket used during development.
2. Adds a new Socorro app called `clear_es_indices`, run during `make dockersetup`, that clears all existing Elasticsearch indexes.
3. Adds a new Socorro app called `create_recent_es_indices`, run during `make dockerupdatedata`, that creates Elasticsearch indices for the next two weeks. This fixes the issues with the homepage and other views that pop up during local development when they're missing.

We don't have great support for testing changes to Elasticsearch, so I filed [bug 1429267](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1429267) as a followup to add better scaffolding such that we could add automated tests for scripts like these.

To test this:
1. Start with a Socorro installation that has processed some crashes.
2. Run `make dockersetup`. You should see logging output that looks something like this:

   ```
   Dropping and recreating S3 bucket...
   S3 container bucket is dev_bucket
   delete: s3://dev_bucket/v1/dump/01557534-e7c7-4936-970d-86f550180107
   (...snip...)
   ```

   You should also see a log line like this, indicating that the existing ES indices have been deleted:

   ```
   2018-01-10 01:22:23,085 DEBUG - clear_es_indices -  - MainThread - Deleted elasticsearch indices.
   ```
3. Run `make dockerupdatedata`. You should see logging output indicating that new ES indices have been created:

   ```
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,754 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201801
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,812 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201802
   2018-01-11 21:13:01,893 INFO - create_recent_es_indices -  - MainThread - Created new elasticsearch index: socorro201803
   ```
4. Run `docker-compose up webapp` and visit http://localhost:8000/home/product/Firefox. You should see a graph on the front page, although it may contain no data (you should not see an error message, which indicates the indices were not found).

pull_requests.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
pull_requests.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

I've faced with error because of this line. The problem is databaseConnection is not updated in the whole loop, so if connection to the database is lost, it will not be established again. I'd recommend to introduce `invalidate` method to the `databaseConnectionPool` or exit monitor at this point.
If an exception was raised, threads in the threadPool are not stopped properly, so the whole process remains alive forewer.

review_comments.body: One of the sessions I attended at DjangoCon pointed out that Postgres doesn't handle this quite like you'd expect. Postgres doesn't start at the offset and count up to the limit; it still figures out the result set and then just returns to you the subset you've asked for. In some cases, Postgres can actually work HARDER with a LIMIT ... OFFSET than it would otherwise. Just FYI in case it ever becomes an issue.
Doubt you actually want this in production. :-)

+import json

+class Search(ElasticSearchCommon, SearchCommon):

+    """
+    Implement the /search service with ElasticSearch.
+    """

+    def __init__(self, config):
+        """
+        Default constructor
+        """
+        #~ super(Search, self).__init__(config)
+        ElasticSearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+        SearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+
+    def search(self, **kwargs):
+        """
+        Search for crashes and return them.
+
+        See http://socorro.readthedocs.org/en/latest/middleware.html#search
+
+        Optional arguments: see SearchCommon.get_parameters()
+
+        """
+        params = Search.get_parameters(kwargs)
+
+        # Get information about the versions
+        versions_service = vi.VersionsInfo(self.context)
+        params["versions_info"] = versions_service.versions_info(params)
+
+        query = Search.build_query_from_params(params)
+
+        # For signatures mode, we need to collect more data with facets
+        types = params["data_type"]
+        if types == "signatures":
+            # No need to get crashes, we only want signatures
+            query["size"] = 0
+            query["from"] = 0
+
+            # Using a fixed number instead of the needed number.
+            # This hack limits the number of distinct signatures to process,
+            # and hugely improves performances with long queries.
+            query["facets"] = Search.get_signatures_facet(

+        else:

`verify_certs=True` and `use_ssl=True` args into the Elasticsearch

issues.body:
This makes it easier to set up initial crontabber bookkeeping state in
the local development environment without having to run all the crontabber
jobs.

Mike: Do you think this helps? Is it good enough for a first pass? We can also do one for marking jobs as failed. I think that covers basic cases and after that it's probably easier to drop into psql and edit the db manually.

issues.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
issues.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

issues.title: Bug 1430181: Add an API endpoint (CrashStopData) to Socorro.
issues.body: The purpose of this endpoint is to have in one shot all the data needed by the webextension CrashStop which displays crash data in Bugzilla.

issues.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
issues.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

issues.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
issues.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1424659 - nix consecutive spaces in signatures

Prior to this, it was possible (though rare) to have two spaces in a row
in signatures. That's tough because the webui shows that as a single
space and if you search for the single-space version, you won't get any
results.

This fixes that by establishing that signatures can't have more than 1
consecutive whitespace character. Further, this makes sure that all
non-space whitespace characters are converted to space and this
happens all before we truncate the signature.

I also changed SigTrunc to SigTruncate because "trunc" is an unnecessary
abbreviation.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1371428 - nix ' to '' in signature generation

For years, there's been a bit of code to "escape single quotes" in
Java and C signatures. As near as I can tell, it predates the current
era of Socorro requirements and was likely added for some reason that
is no longer relevant.

One consequence is that it makes searching for frames harder, so this
removes that behavior.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1416841 - nix .* at end of lines in siglist files

Since each line is a regexp that's joined with others with | and then
used with .match(), they're effectively all "startswith" type matches
so the .* at the end is superfluous.

Mike: Do you think this helps? Is it good enough for a first pass? We can also do one for marking jobs as failed. I think that covers basic cases and after that it's probably easier to drop into psql and edit the db manually.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
pull_requests.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
pull_requests.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

pull_requests.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
pull_requests.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

review_comments.body: One of the sessions I attended at DjangoCon pointed out that Postgres doesn't handle this quite like you'd expect. Postgres doesn't start at the offset and count up to the limit; it still figures out the result set and then just returns to you the subset you've asked for. In some cases, Postgres can actually work HARDER with a LIMIT ... OFFSET than it would otherwise. Just FYI in case it ever becomes an issue.
Doubt you actually want this in production. :-)

+

+            # This hack limits the number of distinct signatures to process,
+            # and hugely improves performances with long queries.
+            query["facets"] = Search.get_signatures_facet(

issues.title: fixes bug 1416340 - use secure args for ES connections
issues.body:
If the `elasticsearch_urls` are all https, then we should be passing in
`verify_certs=True` and `use_ssl=True` args into the Elasticsearch
connection.

issues.title: bug 1431442 - add "mark-success" to crontabber app
issues.body:
This makes it easier to set up initial crontabber bookkeeping state in
the local development environment without having to run all the crontabber
jobs.

Mike: Do you think this helps? Is it good enough for a first pass? We can also do one for marking jobs as failed. I think that covers basic cases and after that it's probably easier to drop into psql and edit the db manually.

issues.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
issues.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

issues.title: Bug 1430181: Add an API endpoint (CrashStopData) to Socorro.
issues.body: The purpose of this endpoint is to have in one shot all the data needed by the webextension CrashStop which displays crash data in Bugzilla.

issues.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
issues.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

issues.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
issues.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1424659 - nix consecutive spaces in signatures

Prior to this, it was possible (though rare) to have two spaces in a row
in signatures. That's tough because the webui shows that as a single
space and if you search for the single-space version, you won't get any
results.

This fixes that by establishing that signatures can't have more than 1
consecutive whitespace character. Further, this makes sure that all
non-space whitespace characters are converted to space and this
happens all before we truncate the signature.

I also changed SigTrunc to SigTruncate because "trunc" is an unnecessary
abbreviation.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1371428 - nix ' to '' in signature generation

For years, there's been a bit of code to "escape single quotes" in
Java and C signatures. As near as I can tell, it predates the current
era of Socorro requirements and was likely added for some reason that
is no longer relevant.

One consequence is that it makes searching for frames harder, so this
removes that behavior.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1416841 - nix .* at end of lines in siglist files

Since each line is a regexp that's joined with others with | and then
used with .match(), they're effectively all "startswith" type matches
so the .* at the end is superfluous.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
pull_requests.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
pull_requests.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

pull_requests.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
pull_requests.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

review_comments.body: One of the sessions I attended at DjangoCon pointed out that Postgres doesn't handle this quite like you'd expect. Postgres doesn't start at the offset and count up to the limit; it still figures out the result set and then just returns to you the subset you've asked for. In some cases, Postgres can actually work HARDER with a LIMIT ... OFFSET than it would otherwise. Just FYI in case it ever becomes an issue.
Doubt you actually want this in production. :-)

@@ -0,0 +1,228 @@
+import json
+import logging
+
+from common import ElasticSearchCommon
+from socorro.lib.search_common import SearchCommon
+import socorro.services.versions_info as vi
+
+logger = logging.getLogger("webapi")
+
+
+class Search(ElasticSearchCommon, SearchCommon):
+
+    """
+    Implement the /search service with ElasticSearch.
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, config):
+        """
+        Default constructor
+        """
+        #~ super(Search, self).__init__(config)
+        ElasticSearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+        SearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+
+    def search(self, **kwargs):
+        """
+        Search for crashes and return them.
+
+        See http://socorro.readthedocs.org/en/latest/middleware.html#search
+
+        Optional arguments: see SearchCommon.get_parameters()
+
+        """
+        params = Search.get_parameters(kwargs)
+
+        # Get information about the versions
+        versions_service = vi.VersionsInfo(self.context)
+        params["versions_info"] = versions_service.versions_info(params)
+
+        query = Search.build_query_from_params(params)
+
+        # For signatures mode, we need to collect more data with facets
+        types = params["data_type"]
+        if types == "signatures":
+            # No need to get crashes, we only want signatures
+            query["size"] = 0
+            query["from"] = 0
+
+            # Using a fixed number instead of the needed number.
+            # This hack limits the number of distinct signatures to process,
+            # and hugely improves performances with long queries.
+            query["facets"] = Search.get_signatures_facet(
+                            self.context.searchMaxNumberOfDistinctSignatures)
+
+        json_query = json.dumps(query)
+        logger.debug("Query the crashes or signatures: %s", json_query)
+
+        es_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                               params["to_date"],
+                               json_query)
+
+        # Executing the query and returning the result
+        if types != "signatures":
+            return es_result
+        else:
+            try:
+                es_data = json.loads(es_result[0])
+            except Exception:
+                logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                             es_result[0])
+                raise
+
+            # Making sure we have a real result before using it
+            if not es_data:
+                signature_count = 0
+            else:
+                signature_count = len(es_data["facets"]["signatures"]["terms"])
+
+            maxsize = min(signature_count,
+                          params["result_number"] + params["result_offset"])
+
+            if maxsize > params["result_offset"]:
+                signatures = Search.get_signatures(
+                                                es_data["facets"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+                count_by_os_query = query
+                facets = Search.get_count_facets(
+                                            signatures,
+                                            params["result_offset"],
+                                            maxsize)
+                count_by_os_query["facets"] = facets
+                count_by_os_query_json = json.dumps(count_by_os_query)
+                logger.debug("Query the OS by signature: %s",
+                             count_by_os_query_json)
+
+                count_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                                          params["to_date"],
+                                          count_by_os_query_json)
+                try:
+                    count_data = json.loads(count_result[0])
+                except Exception:
+                    logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                                 count_result[0])
+                    raise
+
+                count_sign = count_data["facets"]
+                signatures = Search.get_counts(
+                                                signatures,
+                                                count_sign,
+                                                params["result_offset"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+            results = {
+                "total": signature_count,
+                "hits": []
+            }
+
+            for i in xrange(params["result_offset"], maxsize):
+                results["hits"].append(signatures[i])
+
+            return results
+
+    @staticmethod
review_comments.body: Why are all of these static methods? Generally using class methods is preferred and if there's a reason to make it a static method, it might deserve a comment in the code that explains 'why'.

issues.title: fixes bug 1416340 - use secure args for ES connections
issues.body:
If the `elasticsearch_urls` are all https, then we should be passing in
`verify_certs=True` and `use_ssl=True` args into the Elasticsearch
connection.

issues.title: bug 1431442 - add "mark-success" to crontabber app
issues.body:
This makes it easier to set up initial crontabber bookkeeping state in
the local development environment without having to run all the crontabber
jobs.

Mike: Do you think this helps? Is it good enough for a first pass? We can also do one for marking jobs as failed. I think that covers basic cases and after that it's probably easier to drop into psql and edit the db manually.

issues.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
issues.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

issues.title: Bug 1430181: Add an API endpoint (CrashStopData) to Socorro.
issues.body: The purpose of this endpoint is to have in one shot all the data needed by the webextension CrashStop which displays crash data in Bugzilla.

issues.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
issues.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

issues.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
issues.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1424659 - nix consecutive spaces in signatures

Prior to this, it was possible (though rare) to have two spaces in a row
in signatures. That's tough because the webui shows that as a single
space and if you search for the single-space version, you won't get any
results.

This fixes that by establishing that signatures can't have more than 1
consecutive whitespace character. Further, this makes sure that all
non-space whitespace characters are converted to space and this
happens all before we truncate the signature.

I also changed SigTrunc to SigTruncate because "trunc" is an unnecessary
abbreviation.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1371428 - nix ' to '' in signature generation

For years, there's been a bit of code to "escape single quotes" in
Java and C signatures. As near as I can tell, it predates the current
era of Socorro requirements and was likely added for some reason that
is no longer relevant.

One consequence is that it makes searching for frames harder, so this
removes that behavior.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1416841 - nix .* at end of lines in siglist files

Since each line is a regexp that's joined with others with | and then
used with .match(), they're effectively all "startswith" type matches
so the .* at the end is superfluous.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
pull_requests.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
pull_requests.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

pull_requests.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
pull_requests.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

I've faced with error because of this line. The problem is databaseConnection is not updated in the whole loop, so if connection to the database is lost, it will not be established again. I'd recommend to introduce `invalidate` method to the `databaseConnectionPool` or exit monitor at this point.
If an exception was raised, threads in the threadPool are not stopped properly, so the whole process remains alive forewer.

-          LIMIT %(listsize)s"""

review_comments.body: One of the sessions I attended at DjangoCon pointed out that Postgres doesn't handle this quite like you'd expect. Postgres doesn't start at the offset and count up to the limit; it still figures out the result set and then just returns to you the subset you've asked for. In some cases, Postgres can actually work HARDER with a LIMIT ... OFFSET than it would otherwise. Just FYI in case it ever becomes an issue.
Doubt you actually want this in production. :-)

+        ElasticSearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+        SearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+
+    def search(self, **kwargs):
+        """
+        Search for crashes and return them.
+
+        See http://socorro.readthedocs.org/en/latest/middleware.html#search
+
+        Optional arguments: see SearchCommon.get_parameters()
+
+        """
+        params = Search.get_parameters(kwargs)
+
+        # Get information about the versions
+        versions_service = vi.VersionsInfo(self.context)
+        params["versions_info"] = versions_service.versions_info(params)
+
+        query = Search.build_query_from_params(params)
+
+        # For signatures mode, we need to collect more data with facets
+        types = params["data_type"]
+        if types == "signatures":
+            # No need to get crashes, we only want signatures
+            query["size"] = 0
+            query["from"] = 0
+
+            # Using a fixed number instead of the needed number.
+            # This hack limits the number of distinct signatures to process,
+            # and hugely improves performances with long queries.
+            query["facets"] = Search.get_signatures_facet(
+                            self.context.searchMaxNumberOfDistinctSignatures)
+
+        json_query = json.dumps(query)
+        logger.debug("Query the crashes or signatures: %s", json_query)
+
+        es_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                               params["to_date"],
+                               json_query)
+
+        # Executing the query and returning the result
+        if types != "signatures":
+            return es_result
+        else:
+            try:
+                es_data = json.loads(es_result[0])
+            except Exception:
+                logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                             es_result[0])
+                raise
+
+            # Making sure we have a real result before using it
+            if not es_data:
+                signature_count = 0
+            else:
+                signature_count = len(es_data["facets"]["signatures"]["terms"])
+
+            maxsize = min(signature_count,
+                          params["result_number"] + params["result_offset"])
+
+            if maxsize > params["result_offset"]:
+                signatures = Search.get_signatures(
+                                                es_data["facets"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+                count_by_os_query = query
+                facets = Search.get_count_facets(
+                                            signatures,
+                                            params["result_offset"],
+                                            maxsize)
+                count_by_os_query["facets"] = facets
+                count_by_os_query_json = json.dumps(count_by_os_query)
+                logger.debug("Query the OS by signature: %s",
+                             count_by_os_query_json)
+
+                count_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                                          params["to_date"],
+                                          count_by_os_query_json)
+                try:
+                    count_data = json.loads(count_result[0])
+                except Exception:
+                    logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                                 count_result[0])
+                    raise
+
+                count_sign = count_data["facets"]
+                signatures = Search.get_counts(
+                                                signatures,
+                                                count_sign,
+                                                params["result_offset"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+            results = {
+                "total": signature_count,
+                "hits": []
+            }
+
+            for i in xrange(params["result_offset"], maxsize):
+                results["hits"].append(signatures[i])
+
+            return results
+
+    @staticmethod
review_comments.body: Why are all of these static methods? Generally using class methods is preferred and if there's a reason to make it a static method, it might deserve a comment in the code that explains 'why'.

issues.title: fixes bug 1416340 - use secure args for ES connections
issues.body:
If the `elasticsearch_urls` are all https, then we should be passing in
`verify_certs=True` and `use_ssl=True` args into the Elasticsearch
connection.

issues.title: bug 1431442 - add "mark-success" to crontabber app
issues.body:
This makes it easier to set up initial crontabber bookkeeping state in
the local development environment without having to run all the crontabber
jobs.

Mike: Do you think this helps? Is it good enough for a first pass? We can also do one for marking jobs as failed. I think that covers basic cases and after that it's probably easier to drop into psql and edit the db manually.

issues.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
issues.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

issues.title: Bug 1430181: Add an API endpoint (CrashStopData) to Socorro.
issues.body: The purpose of this endpoint is to have in one shot all the data needed by the webextension CrashStop which displays crash data in Bugzilla.

issues.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
issues.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

issues.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
issues.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1424659 - nix consecutive spaces in signatures

Prior to this, it was possible (though rare) to have two spaces in a row
in signatures. That's tough because the webui shows that as a single
space and if you search for the single-space version, you won't get any
results.

This fixes that by establishing that signatures can't have more than 1
consecutive whitespace character. Further, this makes sure that all
non-space whitespace characters are converted to space and this
happens all before we truncate the signature.

I also changed SigTrunc to SigTruncate because "trunc" is an unnecessary
abbreviation.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1371428 - nix ' to '' in signature generation

For years, there's been a bit of code to "escape single quotes" in
Java and C signatures. As near as I can tell, it predates the current
era of Socorro requirements and was likely added for some reason that
is no longer relevant.

One consequence is that it makes searching for frames harder, so this
removes that behavior.

commit.message:
fixes bug 1416841 - nix .* at end of lines in siglist files

Since each line is a regexp that's joined with others with | and then
used with .match(), they're effectively all "startswith" type matches
so the .* at the end is superfluous.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1431162: Fix errors in crontabber_status.js due to D3/sankey updates.
pull_requests.body:
- Fix some inconsistent indenting that was failing eslint.
- The `d.x`, `d.y`, and `d.dy` attributes on sankey datums appears to have been
  replaced with `d.x0`, `d.x1`, `d.y0`, and `d.y1`. So we replace all old
  attributes with the new ones (dy is computed from y0 and y1).
- Pass nodes and links via the sankey constructor.
- Replace `sankey.nodeWidth` call with a property computed from the datum's `x0`
  and `x1` values.
- Replace `sankey.update` with `sankey.relayout`.
- Replace `sankey.link` with `d3.sankeyLinkHorizontal`.

Most of these changes were found in the release notes on the sankey Github:
https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey/releases.

pull_requests.title: Fix bug 1429431: Use pyup to monitor and update e2e-tests dependencies.
pull_requests.body:
This PR does a few things:

1. Moves the dependency config for the e2e-tests into `e2e-tests/requirements/default.txt` and adds a constriants file for indirect dependencies. Both of these files perform hash checks for downloaded packages.
2. Adds the newly-created e2e-tests requirements to the pyup config.
3. Removes the `flake8` environment from the tox config, instead using the existing automation we have for linting python code in CircleCI and TravisCI. I'm not sure if this is being actively run anywhere.

   The downside of this is that we can't ignore line length only for the e2e-tests subdirectory, so I fixed the linting errors that this change brought up.

@stephendonner @chartjes Ya'll probably wanna look over this too before we merge it in case I've unknowingly broken some automation I'm not aware of or am otherwise messing up your stuff. This change will make it so that a PR for updating the test dependencies will be automatically filed once a month by the pyup bot, saving ya'll some human effort. :D

pull_requests.title: Ack RMQ message on exactly same channel
pull_requests.body:
RMQ message should be acknowlodged on same channel and connection it was
recived. Lets store channel near with the message.
Here also removed rety on basic_ack since if ack failed connection or
channel error it means we could not ackowledge task anymore.

What led us to this issue is that if one of RMQ HA Cluster nodes fails we got lots of errors "unknown delivery tag" errors. And due to using transaction for  both `basic_get` and `basic_ack` this error could lead to very long performance degradation on processors. This is because every time "unknown delivery tag"  happen we close connection and all crashes we are processing now will get same error on save.

I've faced with error because of this line. The problem is databaseConnection is not updated in the whole loop, so if connection to the database is lost, it will not be established again. I'd recommend to introduce `invalidate` method to the `databaseConnectionPool` or exit monitor at this point.
If an exception was raised, threads in the threadPool are not stopped properly, so the whole process remains alive forewer.

@@ -30,10 +51,11 @@ class HangReport(webapi.JsonServiceBase):
           WHERE product = %(product)s
           AND version = %(version)s
           AND report_day > utc_day_begins_pacific(((%(end)s)::timestamp - interval '%(duration)s days')::date)
-          LIMIT %(listsize)s"""
+          LIMIT %(listsize)s
+          OFFSET %(offset)s"""
review_comments.body: One of the sessions I attended at DjangoCon pointed out that Postgres doesn't handle this quite like you'd expect. Postgres doesn't start at the offset and count up to the limit; it still figures out the result set and then just returns to you the subset you've asked for. In some cases, Postgres can actually work HARDER with a LIMIT ... OFFSET than it would otherwise. Just FYI in case it ever becomes an issue.
Doubt you actually want this in production. :-)

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,228 @@
+import json
+import logging
+
+from common import ElasticSearchCommon
+from socorro.lib.search_common import SearchCommon
+import socorro.services.versions_info as vi
+
+logger = logging.getLogger("webapi")
+
+
+class Search(ElasticSearchCommon, SearchCommon):
+
+    """
+    Implement the /search service with ElasticSearch.
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, config):
+        """
+        Default constructor
+        """
+        #~ super(Search, self).__init__(config)
+        ElasticSearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+        SearchCommon.__init__(self, config)
+
+    def search(self, **kwargs):
+        """
+        Search for crashes and return them.
+
+        See http://socorro.readthedocs.org/en/latest/middleware.html#search
+
+        Optional arguments: see SearchCommon.get_parameters()
+
+        """
+        params = Search.get_parameters(kwargs)
+
+        # Get information about the versions
+        versions_service = vi.VersionsInfo(self.context)
+        params["versions_info"] = versions_service.versions_info(params)
+
+        query = Search.build_query_from_params(params)
+
+        # For signatures mode, we need to collect more data with facets
+        types = params["data_type"]
+        if types == "signatures":
+            # No need to get crashes, we only want signatures
+            query["size"] = 0
+            query["from"] = 0
+
+            # Using a fixed number instead of the needed number.
+            # This hack limits the number of distinct signatures to process,
+            # and hugely improves performances with long queries.
+            query["facets"] = Search.get_signatures_facet(
+                            self.context.searchMaxNumberOfDistinctSignatures)
+
+        json_query = json.dumps(query)
+        logger.debug("Query the crashes or signatures: %s", json_query)
+
+        es_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                               params["to_date"],
+                               json_query)
+
+        # Executing the query and returning the result
+        if types != "signatures":
+            return es_result
+        else:
+            try:
+                es_data = json.loads(es_result[0])
+            except Exception:
+                logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                             es_result[0])
+                raise
+
+            # Making sure we have a real result before using it
+            if not es_data:
+                signature_count = 0
+            else:
+                signature_count = len(es_data["facets"]["signatures"]["terms"])
+
+            maxsize = min(signature_count,
+                          params["result_number"] + params["result_offset"])
+
+            if maxsize > params["result_offset"]:
+                signatures = Search.get_signatures(
+                                                es_data["facets"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+                count_by_os_query = query
+                facets = Search.get_count_facets(
+                                            signatures,
+                                            params["result_offset"],
+                                            maxsize)
+                count_by_os_query["facets"] = facets
+                count_by_os_query_json = json.dumps(count_by_os_query)
+                logger.debug("Query the OS by signature: %s",
+                             count_by_os_query_json)
+
+                count_result = self.query(params["from_date"],
+                                          params["to_date"],
+                                          count_by_os_query_json)
+                try:
+                    count_data = json.loads(count_result[0])
+                except Exception:
+                    logger.debug("ElasticSearch returned something wrong: %s",
+                                 count_result[0])
+                    raise
+
+                count_sign = count_data["facets"]
+                signatures = Search.get_counts(
+                                                signatures,
+                                                count_sign,
+                                                params["result_offset"],
+                                                maxsize,
+                                                self.context.platforms)
+
+            results = {
+                "total": signature_count,
+                "hits": []
+            }
+
+            for i in xrange(params["result_offset"], maxsize):
+                results["hits"].append(signatures[i])
+
+            return results
+
+    @staticmethod
review_comments.body: Why are all of these static methods? Generally using class methods is preferred and if there's a reason to make it a static method, it might deserve a comment in the code that explains 'why'.
